metadata.name: Relationship Quality & Maintenance Scale
metadata.authors: ThriveIEP / LE3 (adapted from Stafford, 2011; Liang et al., 2002; Cutrona & Russell, 1987)
metadata.citation: ThriveIEP. (2026). Relationship Quality & Maintenance Scale (RQM-6). Based on Stafford, L. (2011). Measuring relationship maintenance behaviors. Journal of Social and Personal Relationships, 28, 278–303; Liang, B., et al. (2002). The Relational Health Indices. Psychology of Women Quarterly, 26, 25–35; Cutrona, C. E., & Russell, D. (1987). The provisions of social relationships and adaptation to stress.
metadata.license: Original scale developed by ThriveIEP for C2A battery. Integrates constructs from relationship maintenance (Stafford, 2011), relational health (Liang et al., 2002), social provisions (Cutrona & Russell, 1987), and gratitude research (Gordon et al., 2012).
metadata.stem: Please indicate how often you have done each of the following in the past month.

items.text: In the past month, how often have you checked in on a classmate, colleague, or peer to see how they were doing — without being asked?
In the past month, how often have you remembered and asked someone about something important going on in their life — like a project, interview, or personal situation they told you about?
In the past month, how often have you opened up to a classmate, colleague, or peer about a challenge you were facing?
In the past month, how often have you expressed appreciation or recognition to someone for their help, effort, or contribution?
In the past month, how often have you made time to have a meaningful conversation with a peer, mentor, or colleague — beyond what was required?
In the past month, how often have you suggested to someone that they talk to another person you know who might be helpful to them?

validation.sample_description: Pilot instrument — no published validation data. Initial target α ≥ .65, refinement target α ≥ .70. Items drawn from relationship maintenance (Stafford, 2011), relational health (Liang et al., 2002), social provisions (Cutrona & Russell, 1987), and gratitude (Gordon et al., 2012) traditions.
